text: relationships can be one of the most
beautiful and rewarding aspects of life
but they're also where we often find
ourselves tested the most if you're
watching this you're probably someone
who values connection and wants to grow
not just for your partner but for
yourself too whether you're in a
relationship navigating life after a
breakup or if you're single and are
simply curious about love your desire to
improve is commendable so how can you
actually become a better partner for a
happier and healthier relationship let's
get into
it examine
yourself before trying to fix the
relationship take a moment to look
inward honest self-reflection is key ask
yourself and if possible your
partner what am I doing well and where
could I improve maybe they feel unheard
or that your emotional
distant don't brush off their complaints
work on them for example if they've said
you don't seem fully present that's
something to focus on think about how
your actions impact your relationship
self-awareness is word transformation
begins and recognizing areas you need to
work on gets you halfway
there embrace your partner's
flaws nobody's perfect and that's okay
accepting each other's imperfections is
is a big part of Love even if there are
things you'd like them to
improve according to relationship
experts our partners often trigger our
own unmet needs acceptance isn't about
ignoring everything it's about showing
empathy while encouraging growth for
example if your partner is always
running late instead of just getting
annoyed you could suggest a
solution how about we set reminders and
leave 15 minutes earlier next time this
shifts the focus from criticism to
teamwork so you're handling it together
you don't have to love every habit about
your partner but you can definitely love
them while encouraging each other to
grow communicate
openly ever been upset with your partner
but they have no idea why yeah those
Supernatural Powers we wish they had
however as relationship expert Esther
Perell points out your partner cannot
read your mind so tell them what's in
your heart be open about your feelings
needs and insecurities even if it's
uncomfortable for example I once worked
with a couple where the wife felt
overwhelmed by chores after becoming a
stay-at-home mom her husband assumed she
could handle everything so he stopped
helping she didn't say anything because
she thought he should just get it but
guess what he had no ideas she she was
struggling when she finally told him how
she felt he apologized and began helping
again clear and regular communication
makes both Partners feel heard supported
and
understood finding this video insightful
like share and subscribe for more
practice empathy and patience when your
partner is going through a tough time
resist the urge to fix things
immediately sometimes they just need you
to listen try asking how can I support
you right now to get a better sense of
what they need also be patient
especially during rough patches both of
you will have moments where you're not
at your best there will be moments when
they get on your nerves and vice versa
so when you feel triggered or tempted to
get angry try to step back and see
things from their perspective patience
doesn't mean you're excusing bad
behavior but it helps you respond calmly
and thoughtfully instead of reacting
impulsively Master emotional regulation
and conflict
resolution during conflicts emotions can
easily take control but learning to
regulate them is essential for resolving
issues healthily instead of yelling or
sending passive aggressive
texts take a deep breath or take a dime
out yeah they work on adults too this
helps you come back to the conversation
with a clear mind ready to resolve the
issue calmly when you do talk aim to
find a solution that works for both
parties rather than win the argument
remember it's not just about what you
say but how you say it use a calm and
respectful tone validate their emotions
even if you don't fully agree and focus
on making each other feel heard instead
of Defending Your actions or assigning
blame speak your partner's love
language Dr Gary Chapman author of The
Five Love Languages explains that each
person feels most loved through one or
two primary ways words of affirmation
acts of service receiving gifts Quality
Time or physical touch for example if
your partner's love language is acts of
service simple gestures like making
breakfast or helping with chores can
make them feel cherished if it's words
of affirmation expressing how much they
mean to you will make them feel special
or if they're all about quality time
just being present no distractions even
for a few minutes will make them feel
loved avoid speaking your own love
language rather than theirs this can
lead to unmet needs and frustration
consistently showing love in their
language will bring out the best in your
relationship ship to be a better partner
focus on avoiding behaviors that can
harm your relationship like constant
fighting lack of support criticism and
hostility instead nurture things that
create a healthy Bond like positive
memories mutual respect
intimacy good communication and making
each other feel valued don't just focus
on what's wrong take time to appreciate
each other and remember to speak your
partner's love language having said that
what's one quality you think makes
someone a great partner let us continue
the discussion in the comments are you
curious about the behaviors that can
destroy relationships check out this
video 10 behaviors that destroy
relationships thanks for watching
[Music]
